# Decision Analysis: Hiring a VP of Engineering Post-Series A

## Step 1: Define Measurable KPIs

| KPI | Definition | Current Baseline (est.) |
|-----|-----------|----------------------|
| **K1: Engineering Velocity** | Features shipped per sprint (or equivalent throughput metric) | Assume ~X story points/sprint; target is meaningful increase within 6 months |
| **K2: Time-to-Productive-Hire** | Months from decision to the point where the chosen solution is actually improving output (net of onboarding drag) | Currently N/A |
| **K3: Cash Runway Consumed** | Total fully-loaded cost of the solution over 12 months as % of remaining runway | Baseline: 0% (do nothing) |

These KPIs capture the core tension: **speed gains vs. cost and execution risk**.

---

## Step 2: Identify the Full Option Set

| # | Option | Description |
|---|--------|-------------|
| **A** | **Hire a VP of Engineering** (as proposed) | Senior hire ($250-400k+ OTE) to manage team, processes, hiring pipeline |
| **B** | **Promote/develop an internal engineering manager** | Elevate a senior engineer into a player-coach EM role |
| **C** | **Hire 2-3 senior ICs instead** | Skip the management layer; add raw capacity |
| **D** | **Fractional / interim VP of Engineering** | Contract VPE (3-6 months) to install processes, then reassess |
| **E** | **Hire a Technical Program Manager (TPM)** | Lighter-weight coordination role; offloads CTO's project management burden without a full exec hire |
| **F** | **Do nothing / status quo** | CTO continues managing; accept current velocity |

*Option D and E are commonly overlooked in this framing.*

---

## Step 3: Point Estimates & 80% Confidence Intervals

### K1: Engineering Velocity Improvement (% increase over baseline at 6-month mark)

| Option | Point Estimate | 80% CI | Rationale |
|--------|---------------|--------|-----------|
| A: VP Eng | +40% | [+10%, +70%] | High ceiling but wide variance — great VPE is transformational, bad one creates chaos |
| B: Internal EM | +20% | [+5%, +35%] | Lower ceiling, but faster to realize; less disruption risk |
| C: Senior ICs | +30% | [+15%, +50%] | Direct capacity add, but without process improvement, may hit coordination ceiling |
| D: Fractional VPE | +25% | [+10%, +45%] | Installs systems quickly; limited by part-time engagement |
| E: TPM | +20% | [+10%, +35%] | Frees CTO significantly; doesn't address team scaling long-term |
| F: Status quo | 0% | [-10%, +5%] | Likely slight decline as team burns out |

### K2: Time to Productive Impact (months)

| Option | Point Estimate | 80% CI | Rationale |
|--------|---------------|--------|-----------|
| A: VP Eng | 5 months | [3, 9] | 2-4 months to hire + 1-3 months onboarding; known to be one of the hardest roles to fill |
| B: Internal EM | 1.5 months | [1, 3] | Already has context; transition period is short |
| C: Senior ICs | 4 months | [3, 6] | Hiring + onboarding; ICs ramp faster than executives |
| D: Fractional VPE | 1.5 months | [1, 3] | Can start within weeks; pre-built playbooks |
| E: TPM | 3 months | [2, 5] | Moderate hiring difficulty; faster ramp than exec |
| F: Status quo | 0 | 0 | Immediate but no improvement |

### K3: 12-Month Fully-Loaded Cost ($K)

| Option | Point Estimate | 80% CI | Notes |
|--------|---------------|--------|-------|
| A: VP Eng | $450K | [$350K, $550K] | Salary + equity + recruiter fees (often 20-25% of Y1 comp) |
| B: Internal EM | $40K | [$20K, $80K] | Comp bump + reduced IC output during transition |
| C: Senior ICs (x3) | $750K | [$600K, $900K] | 3 × $200-250K + recruiting costs |
| D: Fractional VPE | $150K | [$100K, $200K] | ~$2-4K/day, 2-3 days/week, 6 months |
| E: TPM | $220K | [$180K, $280K] | Mid-senior TPM + recruiting |
| F: Status quo | $0 | $0 | Dollar cost zero; opportunity cost high |

---

## Step 4: Relevant Base Rates (Outside View)

| Data Point | Source / Basis |
|-----------|---------------|
| **~40% of VP Eng hires at early-stage startups fail within 18 months** | First Round Capital data; Lighthouse/Notion Capital surveys. Mismatch between "build mode" and "process mode" is the #1 cause. |
| **Median time-to-fill for VP Eng is 4-6 months** | Riviera Partners, industry benchmarks for engineering leadership roles |
| **Series A startups typically have 12-18 months of runway** | A 5-month hiring process + 3-month ramp = consuming 30-45% of your runway timeline before seeing results |
| **Engineering throughput problems at 15 people are almost always coordination/process problems, not people-count problems** | Brooks's Law; "adding manpower to a late project makes it later." Research from DORA/Accelerate supports this — process maturity explains more variance than team size. |
| **CTO-to-VPE transitions are the #1 reported "regretted hire" in Y Combinator post-mortems** | YC internal data shared in office hours / blog posts. The CTO often can't let go, or the VPE can't operate with founder-level ambiguity. |

**The base rate alone — 40% failure rate, 5+ months to impact, at a time when speed is existential — should give serious pause to Option A as an immediate move.**

---

## Step 5: Cognitive Biases in the Framing

| Bias | How it appears |
|------|---------------|
| **Solutionism / Narrative bias** | "CTO is overwhelmed → hire someone to manage" is a clean story. But the bottleneck may be unclear priorities, technical debt, or poor sprint discipline — not a missing person. |
| **Title inflation bias** | Jumping to "VP" when the actual need may be a manager or coordinator. At 15 people, a VP of Eng manages ~8-12 engineers — many excellent candidates will see this as a "glorified EM" and churn. |
| **Anchoring on the org chart** | The implicit mental model is "Google-shaped org." At 15 people, you don't need the same structure. |
| **Omission neglect** | The question as framed omits Options D and E, which may dominate on expected value. |
| **Present bias / urgency framing** | "We can't ship fast enough" creates pressure to make a big move now. But the highest-EV path may be a faster, cheaper intervention first. |
| **Survivorship bias** | You've heard stories of great VPE hires transforming companies. You haven't heard about the 40% that failed quietly. |

---

## Step 6: Recommendation (Expected Value Analysis)

### Simplified Expected Value Calculation

Weighting: K1 (velocity) = 50%, K2 (speed to impact) = 30%, K3 (cost-efficiency, inverted) = 20%

Normalizing each KPI to a 0-10 scale:

| Option | K1 Score | K2 Score | K3 Score | Weighted EV | Risk-Adj. EV* |
|--------|----------|----------|----------|-------------|----------------|
| A: VP Eng | 8 | 3 | 4 | **5.6** | **3.9** (×0.6 for 40% failure rate + long delay risk) |
| B: Internal EM | 5 | 9 | 9 | **7.0** | **6.3** |
| C: Senior ICs | 6 | 5 | 2 | **4.9** | **4.4** |
| **D: Fractional VPE** | **6** | **9** | **8** | **7.3** | **6.9** |
| E: TPM | 5 | 7 | 7 | **6.1** | **5.5** |
| F: Status quo | 1 | 10 | 10 | **5.5** | **5.5** |

*Risk-adjusted EV discounts for probability of failure / mis-hire / organizational disruption.*

---

## Final Recommendation

### **Do NOT hire a full-time VP of Engineering right now.**

### **Instead, execute a two-phase plan:**

**Phase 1 (Start this week — Months 0-3):**
- **Hire a fractional/interim VP of Engineering** (Option D). Engage someone with a playbook for 15→40 person engineering orgs. Task them with:
  - Installing sprint/planning discipline
  - Defining engineering levels and career ladders
  - Identifying whether the real bottleneck is people, process, priorities, or technical debt
  - Beginning the recruiting pipeline for the permanent hire (if validated)
- **Simultaneously promote your strongest senior engineer to Tech Lead / EM** (Option B) to start building internal management muscle.

**Phase 2 (Months 3-6):**
- If the fractional VPE validates that a full-time VP Eng is the right next hire (not a given), you now have:
  - A clearer job spec based on actual gaps identified
  - A warm pipeline already started
  - An internal EM who can partner with (not be threatened by) the new hire
  - Data on whether velocity actually improved from process changes alone

**Why this dominates:**
- **Faster to impact** (weeks, not months)
- **70% cheaper** in the evaluation period
- **Reversible** — if it doesn't work, you've lost $50K and 3 months, not $200K+ and 6 months on a mis-hire
- **Reduces the #1 risk** — hiring the wrong VPE before you know what you actually need

> **The meta-insight:** At 15 people post-Series A, your bottleneck is almost certainly not a missing person in a missing box on an org chart. It's missing systems. A fractional leader installs the systems. Then you'll know whether you need the person.
